title: Speaking, Listening, and Presentation Skills

vocab.definition: A formal talk given to share information with an audience
The people who listen to or watch a presentation
Looking directly at people while speaking to connect with them
Paying full attention and responding thoughtfully to what someone says
Pictures, charts, or objects used to help explain ideas in a presentation

teachingNotes: Practice presentation skills with low-stakes topics. Teach active listening strategies and respectful audience behavior. Emphasize clear speaking and organization.

sample.question: What do we call paying full attention to what someone is saying?

Reading every word from your slides is the best way to present.
Active listening includes nodding and asking questions.
Speaking in a monotone keeps the audience engaged.
Visual aids should be clear and easy to see.
Interrupting a speaker shows you are interested.
Practicing your talk can improve confidence.
Facing away from the audience helps them hear you better.

multiplechoice.question: What are pictures or charts used in presentations called?
Which tip helps your voice be heard?
Which slide is best?
choices: One key point with a large image

multiplechoice.question: Which is a good way to handle a tough question?
choices: Say you'll find out and follow up

multiplechoice.question: Which is best for ending?
choices: Summarize key points and thank the audience

shortanswer.question: What are three important things to remember when giving a presentation?

loud voice, look at audience, stay organized
clear speech, good posture, visual aids
engage the audience, clear structure, practice
